bug.author: ngarneau
bug.summary: [BUG] Reset EpochMetric is assumed to be handled, which shouldn't
bug.description:
Describe the bug EpochMetrics are designed to accumulate statistics for a given Epoch. Given their interface, there is a method to accumulate and a method to retrieve the said metric. If one does not explicitly reset the accumulators within the get_metric method, statistics are wrong. To Reproduce <denchmark-code>class CorrelationMetric(EpochMetric): def __init__(self) -> None: super().__init__() self.scores = list() self.distances = list()
def forward(self, x, y): # Accumulate metrics here e3 = x['e3'] scores = x['scores'] distances = x['distances'] for i, (s, d) in enumerate(zip(scores, distances)): self.scores.append(1 - float(s[e3[i]])) self.distances.append(float(d)) # We append the distance
def get_metric(self): val = np.corrcoef(self.scores, self.distances)[0][1] self.reset() # Forgetting this line is problematic, and people will do! return val
def reset(self) -> None: self.scores = list() self.distances = list() </denchmark-code>
Expected behavior The interface should force to implement the reset method, and IMO the training loop should call it after the end of an epoch, not the get_metric method. Desktop (please complete the following information):
OS: Ubuntu Version 20.20

comments.comment: I've made PR <denchmark-link:https://github.com/GRAAL-Research/poutyne/pull/73>#73</denchmark-link> if we want to go with this option. However, this is a small breaking change. <denchmark-link:https://github.com/davebulaval>@davebulaval</denchmark-link> What do you think?
I think <denchmark-link:https://github.com/ngarneau>@ngarneau</denchmark-link> is right, it was not explicit that reset should be present in and it is more clear to call it as suggested.
